global_flags.description: Enable the built-in emacs(1) command line editor (disables -V if it has been set).
Ignore EOF's from input when interactive.
Enable the built-in vi(1) command line editor (disables -E if it has been set).
Enable asynchronous notification of background job completion.  (UNIMPLEMENTED for 4.4alpha)

Read commands from the command_string operand instead of from the standard input.  Special parameter 0  will  be  set from the command_name operand and the positional parameters ($1, $2, etc.)  set from the remaining argument operands.

If not interactive, exit immediately if any untested command fails.  The exit status of a command is considered to be explicitly  tested if the command is used to control an if, elif, while, or until; or if the command is the left hand operand of an “&&” or “||” operator.
Force the shell to behave interactively.
Make dash act as if it had been invoked as a login shell.
Turn on job control (set automatically when interactive).
If not interactive, read commands but do not execute them.  This is useful for checking the syntax of shell scripts.
Do not attempt to reset effective uid if it does not match uid. This is not set by default to  help  avoid  incorrect usage by setuid root programs via system(3) or popen(3).
Read  commands  from  standard input (set automatically if no file arguments are present).  This option has no effect when set after the shell has already started running (i.e. with set).
Write a message to standard error when attempting to expand a variable that is not set, and if the shell is  not  in‐ teractive, exit immediately.
The shell writes its input to standard error as it is read.  Useful for debugging.
Write each command to standard error (preceded by a ‘+ ’) before it is executed.  Useful for debugging.

subcommands.name: by
subcommands.description: colons. Each entry consists of a directory name. The current directory may be indicated implicitly by an empty directory name, or explicitly by a single period.

subcommands.name: for
subcommands.description: normal or success, and non-zero for failure, error, or a false indication. The man page for each command should indicate the various

subcommands.name: function
subcommands.description: name) are made local to the function and are set to the values given. Then the command given in the function definition is exe‐

subcommands.name: starts
subcommands.description: the command and immediately proceeds onto the next command; otherwise it waits for the command to terminate before proceeding to the next one.

subcommands.name: text
subcommands.description: is subjected to parameter expansion, command substitution, and arithmetic expansion (as described in the section on “Expansions”). If the operator is “<<-” instead of “<<”, then leading tabs in the here-doc-text are stripped.

subcommands.name: the
subcommands.description: BNF in the POSIX 1003.2 document). Essentially though, a line is read and if the first word of the line (or after a control operator)

subcommands.name: this
subcommands.description: case, so that the effect will be as if a new shell had been invoked to handle the ad-hoc shell script, except that the location of hashed commands located in the parent shell will be remembered by the child.
